x= 4.693475814350714075717550352014... which can also be expressed as an infinite non-repeating sequence of digits. This value is called the golden ratio. The golden ratio has many unique properties that have fascinated mathematicians for centuries. It appears in nature, art, and mathematics. In fact, the golden ratio is believed to contribute to the beauty of some natural shapes such as spirals in shells or pine cones. Furthermore, it plays a crucial role in Euclidean geometry by providing the most efficient way of dividing rectangles into smaller rectangles while preserving their aspect ratio (i.e., the relationship between width and height). Additionally, fractals known as the "Julia sets" exhibit self-similarity when plotted using numbers derived from the golden ratio. Lastly, the golden ratio can be used to construct regular pentagons and pentagrams, two five-sided geometric figures that share similarities with each other but differ significantly from squares, triangles, and circles, whose construction only requires basic arithmetic operations and compass and ruler techniques."

You can find more information about the golden ratio at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_ratio and learn how to calculate its values online at https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=golden+ratio .
